owl:Ontology.terms:creator: Alexander New
Deborah L. McGuinness
John S. Erickson
Kristin P. Bennett
Miao Qi
Sabbir M. Rashid
Shruthi Chari
owl:Ontology.terms:description: The Health Analysis Ontology includes attributes useful for informing analysis design, summarizing analysis results for later comparison, and for generating reports. It captures the data domain and analysis workflow in cartridges that represent domain knowledge, analytics knowledge, and other components of the analysis pipeline
owl:Ontology.terms:title: Health Analysis Ontology

owl:Class.terms:description: A variable specification that specifies a variable that may have a causal impact on both the independent variable and dependent variable; ignoring a confounding variable may bias empirical estimates of the causal effect of the independent variable.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: confounding variable specification
p-value
owl:Class.skos:definition: A quantitative confidence value that represents the probability of obtaining a result at least as extreme as that actually obtained, assuming that the actual value was the result of chance alone.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: FWER adjusted p-value
owl:Class.skos:definition: A quantitative confidence value resulting from a multiple testing error correction method which adjusts the p-value used as input to control for Type I error in the context of multiple pairwise tests.

owl:Class.terms:description: A planned process that produces output data from input data.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: data transformation

owl:Class.terms:description: A logarithmic transformation is a data transformation consisting in the application of the logarithm function with a given base a (where a>0 and a is not equal to 1) to a (one dimensional) positive real number input. The logarithm function with base a can be defined as the inverse of the exponential function with the same base. See e.g. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logarithm.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: logarithmic transformation

owl:Class.terms:description: The standard error of the mean (SEM) is data item denoting the standard deviation of the sample-mean's estimate of a population mean.It is calculated by dividing the sample standard deviation (i.e., the sample-based estimate of the standard deviation of the population) by the square root of n , the size (number of observations) of the sample.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: standard error of the mean

owl:Class.terms:description: Statistical sample size is a count evaluating the number of individual experimental units
owl:Class.rdfs:label: study group population size

owl:Class.terms:description: linear regression model is a model which attempts to explain data distribution associated with response/dependent variable in terms of values assumed by the independent variable uses a linear function or linear combination of the regression parameters and the predictor/independent variable(s).Linear regression modeling makes a number of assumptions, which includes homoskedasticity (constance of variance)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: linear regression for analysis of continuous dependent variable

owl:Class.terms:description: binomial logistic regression model is a model which attempts to explain data distribution associated with *dichotomous* response/dependent variable in terms of values assumed by the independent variable uses a function of predictor/independent variable(s): the function used in this instance of regression modeling is logistic function.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: binomial logistic regression for analysis of dichotomous dependent variable

owl:Class.terms:description: variable distribution is data item which denotes the spatial resolution of data point making up a variable. variable distribution may be compared to a known probability distribution using goodness of fit test or plotting a quantile-quantile plot for visual assessment of the fit.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: data distribution

owl:Class.terms:description: a normal distribution is a continuous probability distribution described by a probability distribution function described here: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/NormalDistribution.html
owl:Class.rdfs:label: normal distribution

owl:Class.terms:description: The standard deviation of a random variable, statistical population, data set, or probability distribution is a measure of variation which correspond to the average distance from the mean of the data set to any given point of that dataset. It also corresponds to the square root of its variance.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: standard deviation

owl:Class.terms:description: A continuous variable is one for which, within the limits the variable ranges, any value is possible.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: continuous variabl

owl:Class.terms:description: a categorical variable is a variable which that can only assume a finite number of value and cast observation in a small number of categories
owl:Class.rdfs:label: categorical variable

owl:Class.terms:description: a variable is a data item which can assume any of a set of values, either as determined by an agent or as randomly occuring through observation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: variable

owl:Class.terms:description: A regression model is a statistical model used in a type of analysis knowns as regression analysis, whereby a function is used to determine the relation between a response variable and an independent variable , with a set of unknown parameters.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: regression model

owl:Class.terms:description: It is a measure of how precise is an estimate of the statistical parameter is.Standard error is the estimated standard deviation of an estimate. It measures the uncertainty associated with the estimate. Compared with the standard deviations of the underlying distribution, which are usually unknown, standard errors can be calculated from observed data.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: standard error of estimate

owl:Class.terms:description: A regression coefficient is a data item generated by a type of data transformation called a regression, which aims to model a response variable by expression the predictor variables as part of a function where variable terms are modified by a number. A regression coefficient is one such number.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: regression coefficient

owl:Class.terms:description: An algorithm is an effective method expressed as a finite list of well-defined instructions for calculating a function.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: algorithm

owl:Class.terms:description: A category is a class of entities having particular shared characteristics.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: category

owl:Class.terms:description: A central tendency measure is a central value or a typical value for a probability distribution.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: centrality measure

owl:Class.terms:description: A concept is term that refers to a generalization of a set of attributes or entities.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: concept

owl:Class.terms:description: AND is a logical operator that has the value true if both of its operands are true, otherwise a value of false.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: conjunction (and)

owl:Class.terms:description: A control variable that is believed to alter the dependent or independent variables, but may not actually be the focus of the experiment. So that variable will be kept constant or monitored to try to minimise its effect on the experiment.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: control variable

owl:Class.terms:description: The number of elements of a finite set of objects.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: count

owl:Class.terms:description: A definition is a description that succintly characterizes an entity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: definition

owl:Class.terms:description: A description is language entity in which elements of a language (formal or natural) are used to characterize an entity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: description

owl:Class.terms:description: A dimensionless quantity is a quantity that has no associated unit.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: dimensionless quantity

owl:Class.terms:description: Information content entity is an object that requires some background knowledge or procedure to correctly interpret.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: information content entity

owl:Class.terms:description: An informational quality is a quality that pertains to information.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: informational quality

owl:Class.terms:description: A language entity implements some language specification for the visual interpretation and is part of some document.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: language entity

owl:Class.terms:description: Likelihood is the hypothetical probability that an event that has already occurred would yield a specific outcome.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: likelihood

owl:Class.terms:description: A logical operator is a unary or binary relation to construct logical expressions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: logical operator

owl:Class.terms:description: A mathematical entity is an information content entity that are components of a mathematical system or can be defined in mathematical terms.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mathematical entity

owl:Class.terms:description: A maximal value is largest value of an attribute for the entities in the defined set.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: maximal value

owl:Class.terms:description: A mean is the central tendency of a collection of numbers taken as the sum of the numbers divided by the size of the collection.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mean

owl:Class.terms:description: A measurement value is a quantitative description that reflects the magnitude of some attribute.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: measurement value

owl:Class.terms:description: A minimal value is smallest value of an attribute for the entities in the defined set.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: minimal value

owl:Class.terms:description: A mode is the value that appears most often in a set of data.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mode

owl:Class.terms:description: A model is a representation of some thing.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: model

owl:Class.terms:description: A number is a mathematical object used to count, label, and measure.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: number

owl:Class.terms:description: An object is an entity that is wholly identifiable at any instant of time during which it exists.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: object

owl:Class.terms:description: A phrase is a group of words functioning as a single unit in the syntax of a sentence.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: phrase

owl:Class.terms:description: A process is an entity that is identifiable only through the unfolding of time, has temporal parts, and unless otherwise specified/predicted, cannot be identified from any instant of time in which it exists.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: process

owl:Class.terms:description: A quality is an attribute that is intrinsically associated with its bearer (or its parts), but whose presence/absence and observed/measured value may vary.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: quality

owl:Class.terms:description: A quantity is an informational entity that gives the magnitude of a property.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: quantity

owl:Class.terms:description: A representation is a entity that in some way represents another entity (or attribute thereof).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: representation

owl:Class.terms:description: A standard deviation (represented by the symbol σ) is the quantity of variation from the average (mean, or expected value).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: standard deviation

owl:Class.terms:description: A term is a word or phrase used to denote one or more entities.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: term

owl:Class.terms:description: A variable is a value that may change within the scope of a given problem or set of operations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: variable
analysis question
owl:Class.skos:definition: Natural language description of what question a given analysis answers
owl:Class.skos:example: Are higher exposure amounts of a risk factor significantly associated with the presence of heart disease?

owl:Class.terms:description: An analysis workflow is a set of steps used to begin and complete an analysis. It includes defining the problem, preparing the data, training a statistical model, and representing the results.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: analysis workflow

owl:Class.terms:description: Mean and standard-error-of-mean estimates for the entire cohort specified by cohort cartridge.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: base rate
binary variable
owl:Class.skos:definition: Variable taking values of 0 and 1.

owl:Class.terms:description: A cadre assignment function maps a subject record to a probability distribution characterizing that subject's probability of belonging to one of M cadres.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cadre assignment

owl:Class.terms:description: How many subpopulations the cohort specified by the cohort cartridge was divided into after conclusion of model-selection.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cadre count

owl:Class.terms:description: An index assigned to each subpopulation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cadre index

owl:Class.terms:description: How many observations each subpopulation contains.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cadre size

owl:Class.terms:description: The number of subjects in the training data assigned to each cadre.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cadre size list
cartridge
owl:Class.skos:definition: Minimal necessary analysis components from the HAO are stored in modular serializations called cartridges. Given a KG, a cartridge is a subgraph containing application-specific (in this case, analysis-specific) vocabularies that link to the KG’s existing elements and extend the range of problems it may be applied to. In semantalytics, cartridges are loaded and modifiedas the user chooses how to construct their risk analysis study.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: code
owl:Class.skos:definition: String sequence used to represent a constructed response variable in data tables

owl:Class.terms:description: Inclusion criteria used to determine if a given subject may be included in the user's study, which can be chosen on-the-fly or adapted from existing studies.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cohort cartridge
owl:Class.skos:definition: Cohort cartridges list the inclusion criteria used to determine if a given subject may be included in the user’s study.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: component
owl:Class.skos:definition: Category of data tables in NHANES

owl:Class.rdfs:label: condition
owl:Class.skos:definition: Mathematical definition of component of response variable definition, containing relationship, right-hand side, and left-hand side

owl:Class.rdfs:label: conjunction
owl:Class.skos:definition: Mathematical operator used to combine expressions in response variable definitions

owl:Class.terms:description: In a subpopulation cartridge, this is the (survey-weighted) estimated mean of a covariate, calculated over the subjects in a specific subpopulation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: covariate mean

owl:Class.terms:description: In a subpopulation cartridge, this is the (survey-weighted) standard error of the (survey-weighted) estimate of the mean of a covariate, calculated over the subjects in a specific subpopulation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: covariate standard error
data type
owl:Class.skos:definition: Data type of response variable

owl:Class.terms:description: The elastic net mixing weight, a number between 0 and 1, controls whether a given parameter's regularization looks more like l1 regularization or l2 regularization.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: elastic net mixing weight

owl:Class.terms:description: Alpha d, the elastic net mixing weights for the d parameter.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: elastic net mixing weight D

owl:Class.terms:description: Alpha W, the elastic net mixing weights for the W parameter.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: elastic net mixing weight W

owl:Class.terms:description: An estimate is a coefficient from a statistical model quantifying the association between a risk factor and a response variable.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: estimate
exception
owl:Class.skos:definition: Variable names in risk factor tables that have names that look like risk factors but aren’t

owl:Class.terms:description: The name of the parameter d.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cadre assignment feature selection parameter

owl:Class.terms:description: How to divide supplied features into cadre-assignment and target-prediction categories.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: feature usage
file key
owl:Class.skos:definition: Character sequence mapping risk factor categories to data table filenames
owl:Class.skos:example: Data table filenames containing “ins” contain risk factor measurements of the category Organophosphate Insecticides

owl:Class.terms:description: During model selection, a model is trained with every hyperparameter configuration, and a best model is chosen with respect to a supplied metric.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hyperparameter

owl:Class.terms:description: Each column of the parameter W defines a hyperplane which determines each cadre's target prediction function.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hyperplane parameter
input cartridge
owl:Class.skos:definition: Type of cartridge used to define input parameters / configurations when constructing a study

owl:Class.rdfs:label: left hand side
owl:Class.skos:definition: Left-hand side of expression in response variable definitions

owl:Class.rdfs:label: left skewed data distribution
owl:Class.skos:definition: Characteristic of univariate random variables denoting some sort of asymmetry in distribution. Often indicated by having a mean less than the median, and a left-hand tail that is longer than the right-hand tail.

owl:Class.terms:description: How to choose the best model. For population health, this is the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC); for other problems, it could be (e.g.) generalization error.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: metric

owl:Class.terms:description: Minimum number of positive observations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: minimum positive

owl:Class.terms:description: The hyperparameters used to train a model, the parameter estimates learned during training, and the rules by which it is applied to new observations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: model cartridge
owl:Class.skos:definition: Model cartridges assocatiated with a .pkl file gives the parameters and hyperparameters of the associated SCM. The SCM class contains methods to assign observations to new cadres.

owl:Class.terms:description: A model parameter is a data item which is part of a model and which is meant to characterize an theoritecal or unknown population. A model parameter may be estimated by considering the properties of samples presumably taken from the theoritecal population.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: model parameter

owl:Class.terms:description: A note to describe the data in the file.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: note
output cartridge
owl:Class.skos:definition: Type of cartridge that stores an analysis’ statistical findings and links to input cartridges used to define them
owl:Class.skos:example: Results cartridge describing environmental risk factors for hypertension in obese women

owl:Class.terms:description: Rules to complete chosen analysis workflow and potential hyperparameter configurations for chosen model.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: parameter cartridge
owl:Class.skos:definition: Parameter cartridges contain rules to complete the chosen analysis workflow.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: right hand side
owl:Class.skos:definition: Right-hand side of expression in response variable definitions

owl:Class.terms:description: Regularization strength, a nonnegative number, controls the tradeoff between a model that is simple and one that fits the training data well.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: regularization strength

owl:Class.terms:description: Regularization strength for the d parameter.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: regularization strength d

owl:Class.terms:description: Regularization strength for the W parameter.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: regularization strength W
relationship
owl:Class.skos:definition: Mathematical operator used in response variable definitions

owl:Class.terms:description: Analysis concepts and background domain axioms necessary to model a given health condition.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: response cartridge
owl:Class.skos:definition: Response variable cartridges provide the analysis concepts and background domain axioms necessary to model a given disease

owl:Class.terms:description: A result usually refers to an inference drawn from a statistical model. We often summarize the result of an association between a risk factor and a response variable with a coefficient estimate, standard error, and p-value.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: result

owl:Class.terms:description: Quantification of subpopulation-specific discovered associations between the risk factor and the response variable using regression coefficients, standard errors, and p-values
owl:Class.rdfs:label: result cartridge
owl:Class.skos:definition: Type of output cartridge describing a single study’s statistical findings and constituent input cartridges

owl:Class.rdfs:label: right skewed data distribution
owl:Class.skos:definition: Characteristic of univariate random variables denoting some sort of asymmetry in distribution. Often indicated by having a mean greater than the median, and a left-hand tail that is shorter than the right-hand tail.
owl:Class.skos:example: Most environmental exposure risk factor distributions

owl:Class.terms:description: A risk factor is a variable that has a potential association with a response variable.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: risk factor

owl:Class.terms:description: How categories of semantically-similar risk factors should be modeled.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: risk factor cartridge
owl:Class.skos:definition: Risk factor cartridges describe categories of semantically similar risk factors and detail how they should be modeled.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: risk factor category
owl:Class.skos:definition: Category of similar potential risk factors, where “similarity” is defined by domain experts

owl:Class.terms:description: The sharpness hyperparameter affects how quickly, as a subject's attributes shift, their cadre assignment function shifts.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sharpness
Standardization Transformation
owl:Class.skos:definition: Mathematical transformation is applied to univariate random variables. The transformed distribution is shifted and scaled so it has a mean of zero and a variance of one.

owl:Class.rdfs:label: study variable
owl:Class.skos:definition: Variable that potentially has a significant association with the response variable

owl:Class.terms:description: Summary statistics characterizing discovered subpopulations, including within-subpopulation variable means and rates.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: subpopulation cartridge
owl:Class.skos:definition: Subpopulation cartridges give 'Table 1s' (cohort-description tables) of discovered subpopulations.

owl:Class.terms:description: Mean and standard-error-of-mean estimates for each discovered subpopulation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: subpopulation characteristic

owl:Class.terms:description: The maximum number of stochastic gradient descent steps taken.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: T max

owl:Class.terms:description: A target prediction function maps a subject record to a subpopulation-specific score. If the analysis problem is classification, the score gives that subject's risk of having a condition. If the analysis problem is regression, the score is a scaled estimate of the subject's response variable value.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: target prediction
target variable
owl:Class.skos:definition: Variable used as response variable / target feature in modeling analyses
